edge.target: The old man seems unbothered by sitting over a grave and even encourages Lucy to do the same because he doesn't believe that the spirits of the dead would harm the living. He has been sitting on the same spot, which happens to be a grave, for nearly twenty years without any harm. He dismisses the idea that tombstones are for pleasing relatives and suggests that they serve a purpose for the dead. According to him, tombstones bear the truth about the dead, and taking them to the Day of Judgment would mean bringing their sins to light. He also implies that the dead need tombstones to identify themselves in the afterlife. The old man's attitude suggests a deep-seated belief in the supernatural and the afterlife, which is why he is not concerned about sitting on a grave.

edge.target: The 'aboon folk' referred to by Mr. Swales are the people who have died and are buried in the graveyard or 'steans' as he calls it. However, the statement about burying empty caskets is a metaphorical one. Mr. Swales is implying that many of the people buried in the graveyard did not die in Whitby, but rather at sea or in other places, and their bodies were never recovered. Therefore, when their relatives had a tombstone made for them, it was essentially an 'empty casket' or a grave with no body in it. This is exemplified by the grave of Edward Spencelagh, who was murdered by pirates off the coast of Andres and whose body was not brought back to Whitby for burial.

"But," I said, "surely you are not quite correct, for you start on the assumption that all the poor people, or their spirits, will have to take their tombstones with them on the Day of Judgment. Do you think that will be really necessary?"
"Well, what else be they tombstones for? Answer me that, miss!"
"To please their relatives, I suppose."

all these steans be aboon folk that be happed here, snod an' snog?" I assented again. "Then that be just where the lie comes in. Why, there be scores of these lay-beds that be toom as old Dun's 'bacca-box on Friday night." He nudged one of his companions, and they all laughed. "And my gog! how could they be otherwise? Look at that one, the aftest abaft the bier-bank: read it!" I went over and read:--
"Edward Spencelagh, master mariner, murdered by pirates off the coast of Andres, April, 1854, aet. 30." When I came back Mr. Swales went on:--
"Who brought him home, I wonder, to hap him here? Murdered off the coast of Andres! an' you consated his body lay under! edge.target: The harbor is located between two granite piers with lighthouses at their ends, and has a reef that extends for half a mile with a buoy and bell at its end. At high tide, the harbor is filled with water, but at low tide, it becomes a shallow stream of the Esk river, flowing between banks of sand with rocks here and there. The surrounding buildings include a long granite wall on the far side of the harbor, with a curve outwards at the end, and a heavy sea-wall that runs along outside of it. On the near side, the sea-wall makes an elbow crooked inversely, and its end also has a lighthouse. Fishing boats are often seen racing for home and bending to the scuppers as they sweep into the harbor. The wind, which is personified as a woman, changes direction with every puff.

edge.source: The old man seems unbothered by sitting over a grave and even encourages Lucy to do the same because he doesn't believe that the spirits of the dead would harm the living. He has been sitting on the same spot, which happens to be a grave, for nearly twenty years without any harm. He dismisses the idea that tombstones are for pleasing relatives and suggests that they serve a purpose for the dead. According to him, tombstones bear the truth about the dead, and taking them to the Day of Judgment would mean bringing their sins to light. He also implies that the dead need tombstones to identify themselves in the afterlife. The old man's attitude suggests a deep-seated belief in the supernatural and the afterlife, which is why he is not concerned about sitting on a grave.
edge.target:
:--
"Oh, why did you tell us of this? It is my favourite seat, and I cannot leave it; and now I find I must go on sitting over the grave of a suicide."
"That won't harm ye, my pretty; an' it may make poor Geordie gladsome to have so trim a lass sittin' on his lap. That won't hurt ye. Why, I've sat here off an' on for nigh twenty years past, an' it hasn't done me no harm. Don't ye fash about them as lies under ye, or that doesn' lie there either! It'll be time for ye to be getting scart when ye see the tombsteans all run away with, and the place as bare as a stubble-field. There's the clock, an' I must gang. My service to ye, ladies!" And off he hobbled.
Lucy and I sat awhile, and it was all so beautiful before us that we took hands as we sat; and she told me all over again about Arthur and their coming marriage. That made me just a little heart-s

ago with Lucy, and we had a most interesting talk with my old friend and the two others who always come and join him. He is evidently the Sir Oracle of them, and I should think must have been in his time a most dictatorial person. He will not admit anything, and downfaces everybody. If he can't out-argue them he bullies them, and then takes their silence for agreement with his views. Lucy was looking sweetly pretty in her white lawn frock; she has got a beautiful colour since she has been here. I noticed that the old men did not lose any time in coming up and sitting near her when we sat down. She is so sweet with old people; I think they all fell in love with her on the spot. Even my old man succumbed and did not contradict her, but gave me double share instead. I got him on the subject of the legends, and he went off at once into a sort of sermon. I must try to remember it and put it down:--

edge.source: The passage describes a gloomy and stormy weather condition at Kettleness, where Mina Murray currently is. The sea is tumbling in over the shallows with a roar, the horizon is lost in a grey mist, and there is a "brool" over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom. Additionally, Mina mentions that she hasn't received any recent news from Jonathan, which causes her concern. Despite seeing lights scattered around the town, hearing distant sounds, and the band playing on the pier, she hasn't heard any news from Jonathan, and this delay in his correspondence might be due to his preoccupation with his work or some unforeseen circumstances during his journey. The lack of information leaves Mina, and the reader, anxious about Jonathan's well-being.
edge.target:
* * *
_27 July._--No news from Jonathan. I am getting quite uneasy about him, though why I should I do not know; but I do wish that he would write, if it were only a single line. Lucy walks more than ever, and each night I am awakened by her moving about the room. Fortunately, the weather is so hot that she cannot get cold; but still the anxiety and the perpetually being wakened is beginning to tell on me, and I am getting nervous and wakeful myself. Thank God, Lucy's health keeps up. Mr. Holmwood has been suddenly called to Ring to see his father, who has been taken seriously ill. Lucy frets at the postponement of seeing him, but it does not touch her looks; she is a trifle stouter, and her cheeks are a lovely rose-pink. She has lost that anaemic look which she had. I pray it will all last.
* * * *

She is thrilled about receiving three marriage proposals on the same day, including one from Arthur, and cannot hide her excitement and happiness. However, she does not explicitly mention Arthur's response to her declaration of love.
Lucy describes her feelings in great detail, expressing her love for Arthur repeatedly and with enthusiasm. She wishes she could share her emotions with Mina in person, and she asks Mina to keep this a secret. Lucy also expresses her eagerness to hear from Mina and share more about her feelings and the situation.
The letter implies that Lucy is engaged to Jonathan Harker, as both Arthur Holmwood and Quincey P. Morris are eager to attend a party celebrating their friend Jonathan's engagement. However, the specific details of Jonathan and Lucy's engagement are not provided in the letters or narrative excerpts given.
Overall, Lucy's letter to Mina is a candid and heartfelt expression of her love and happiness, although the response from her beloved Arthur remains uncertain.

Mina Murray currently has several anxieties and concerns. She is worried about her fiancé, Jonathan Harker, as she has not received any letters from him for some time. This delay in correspondence, despite seeing lights and hearing distant sounds in the town where she is staying, leaves her anxious about his well-being.

Mina seems to be aware of this man's identity, possibly through rumors or acquaintances, but she has not revealed it in her journal entry.

This curiosity, along with Dr. Seward's connection to Mr. Holmwood, who knows both Mina and the man Lucy is in love with, might be another source of anxiety for Mina.

I could see from the old fellow's self-satisfied air and the way in which he looked round for the approval of his cronies that he was "showing off," so I put in a word to keep him going:--
"Oh, Mr. Swales, you can't be serious. Surely these tombstones are not all wrong?"
"Yabblins! There may be a poorish few not wrong, savin' where they make out the people too good; for there be folk that do think a balm-bowl be like the sea, if only it be their own. The whole thing be only lies. Now look you here; you come here a stranger, an' you see this kirk-garth." I nodded, for I thought it better to assent, though I did not quite understand his dialect. edge.target: "It be all fool-talk, lock, stock, and barrel; that's what it be, an' nowt else. These bans an' wafts an' boh-ghosts an' barguests an' bogles an' all anent them is only fit to set bairns an' dizzy women a-belderin'. They be nowt but air-blebs. They, an' all grims an' signs an' warnin's, be all invented by parsons an' illsome beuk-bodies an' railway touters to skeer an' scunner hafflin's, an' to get folks to do somethin' that they don't other incline to. It makes me ireful to think o' them. Why, it's them that, not content with printin' lies on paper an' preachin' them out of pulpits, does want to be cuttin' them on the tombstones. "_9 May._
"My dearest Lucy,--
"Forgive my long delay in writing, but I have been simply overwhelmed with work. The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying. I am longing to be with you, and by the sea, where we can talk together freely and build our castles in the air. I have been working very hard lately, because I want to keep up with Jonathan's studies, and I have been practising shorthand very assiduously. When we are married I shall be able to be useful to Jonathan, and if I can stenograph well enough I can take down what he wants to say in this way and write it out for him on the typewriter, at which also I am practising very hard. He and I sometimes write letters in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic journal of his travels abroad. When I am with you I shall keep a diary in the same way. I don't mean one of those two-pages-to-the-week-with-Sunday-squeezed-in-a-corner diaries, but a sort of journal which I can write

edge.target: The three men who proposed to Lucy Westenra on the same day are Arthur Holmwood, Dr. John Seward, and Quincey P. Morris. Lucy only felt sorry for two of them because she was truly and deeply in love with Arthur Holmwood (number one) and had no intention of marrying the other two. She considered the proposals of Dr. John Seward (number two) and Quincey P. Morris (number three) to be unnecessary, as she had already made her choice. She felt sympathy for them since they were unaware of her feelings for Arthur and had proposed to her in good faith.

edge.source: Quincey P. Morris has planned a party to celebrate the engagement of their friend Jonathan Harker, as implied by the guests invited - himself, Arthur Holmwood, and Dr. Jack Seward. "Arthur has just gone, and I feel in better spirits than when I left off, so I can go on telling you about the day. Well, my dear, number Two came after lunch. He is such a nice fellow, an American from Texas, and he looks so young and so fresh that it seems almost impossible that he has been to so many places and has had such adventures. I sympathise with poor Desdemona when she had such a dangerous stream poured in her ear, even by a black man. edge.target: The harbor is located between two granite piers with lighthouses at their ends, and has a reef that extends for half a mile with a buoy and bell at its end. At high tide, the harbor is filled with water, but at low tide, it becomes a shallow stream of the Esk river, flowing between banks of sand with rocks here and there. The surrounding buildings include a long granite wall on the far side of the harbor, with a curve outwards at the end, and a heavy sea-wall that runs along outside of it. On the near side, the sea-wall makes an elbow crooked inversely, and its end also has a lighthouse. Fishing boats are often seen racing for home and bending to the scuppers as they sweep into the harbor. The wind, which is personified as a woman, changes direction with every puff.

edge.source: The objective of Renfield's fixed scheme is to absorb as many lives as he can in a cumulative way. He starts by giving many flies to one spider, then many spiders to one bird, and so on. He has a unique mental state, which Dr. Seward describes as a "zooephagous" (life-eating) mania. Renfield's interest in catching flies is likely because they are easy to catch and accumulate in large numbers, making them an ideal starting point for his "experiment." Despite his apparent love for animals, his behavior is not driven by typical motivations, but rather by his unusual and potentially dangerous mental state. He sees animals as a means to an end in his quest to absorb lives.
edge.target:
Renfield's obsession with having a cat is significant because it shows his continued progression in his "zooephagous" scheme. Just as he started with flies, then moved on to spiders and birds, a cat would represent the next step in his plan to absorb lives in a cumulative way. The cat is also a predator, which aligns with his desire for power and control.
Renfield's behavior of fly-catching and humming a tune is related to his state of mind as it shows his persistence and determination in carrying out his plan. Despite the setbacks, such as his birds flying away and the protagonist denying him a cat, Renfield remains undeterred and continues with his fly-catching. The tune he is humming could be indicative of his mood, possibly one of satisfaction or even excitement as he prepares for the next stage of his "experiment."
Overall, Renfield's behavior suggests a fixed and escalating obsession, driven by his unique mental state, which is a cause for concern for the protagonist and the staff looking after him.

edge.target:
great reef, the sharp edge of which runs straight out from behind the south lighthouse. At the end of it is a buoy with a bell, which swings in bad weather, and sends in a mournful sound on the wind. They have a legend here that when a ship is lost bells are heard out at sea. I must ask the old man about this; he is coming this way....
He is a funny old man. He must be awfully old, for his face is all gnarled and twisted like the bark of a tree. He tells me that he is nearly a hundred, and that he was a sailor in the Greenland fishing fleet when Waterloo was fought. He is, I am afraid, a very sceptical person, for when I asked him about the bells at sea and the White Lady at the abbey he said very brusquely:--
"I wouldn't fash masel' about them, miss. Them things be all wore out. Mind, I don't say that they never was, but I do say that they wasn't in my time. They be all very well for comers and trippers, an' the like, but

edge.source: According to the old man, Mr. Swales, he thinks that the stories about bells heard at sea and a White Lady at the abbey are just for tourists and are "all wore out" and "be aboon folk that be happened here, snod an' snog." He suggests that these legends are not based in reality and are not something that he experienced during his time as a sailor.

edge.target: the girl was built up in the wall. It is a most noble ruin, of immense size, and full of beautiful and romantic bits; there is a legend that a white lady is seen in one of the windows. Between it and the town there is another church, the parish one, round which is a big graveyard, all full of tombstones. This is to my mind the nicest spot in Whitby, for it lies right over the town, and has a full view of the harbour and all up the bay to where the headland called Kettleness stretches out into the sea. It descends so steeply over the harbour that part of the bank has fallen away, and some of the graves have been destroyed. In one place part of the stonework of the graves stretches out over the sandy pathway far below. There are walks, with seats beside them, through the churchyard; and people go and sit there all day long looking at the beautiful view and enjoying the breeze. I shall come and sit here very often myself and work. Indeed, I am writing now, with my book on my knee, and listening to the talk of three old men

Lucy, in the narrative, received a passionate love confession from a man who previously seemed carefree and playful due to several factors. First, Lucy has just confessed her love for Arthur Holmwood, which might have encouraged the man to express his feelings, hoping for a similar positive response. Second, Lucy mentions that the man seemed serious and earnest, which is a departure from his usual playful demeanor. This change could be because he has realized his true feelings for Lucy and wants to share them honestly.
Lucy's response to his sudden change in demeanor is one of surprise and a bit of apprehension, as she notes that something in her face checked him. However, she is also touched by his "manly fervor" and could have loved him for it if she had been free. Despite her initial shock, Lucy maintains her composure and listens to his confession, later sharing her happiness with her friend Mina Murray in her letter.
In summary, Lucy becomes the recipient of a passionate love confession from a previously carefree and playful man due to her own declaration of love and the man's decision to share his feelings honestly. Lucy responds with a mix of surprise, apprehension, and appreciation for his sincerity.

so on so grave, so momentous, an occasion for him, I would forgive him. He really did look serious when he was saying it, and I couldn't help feeling a bit serious too--I know, Mina, you will think me a horrid flirt--though I couldn't help feeling a sort of exultation that he was number two in one day. And then, my dear, before I could say a word he began pouring out a perfect torrent of love-making, laying his very heart and soul at my feet. He looked so earnest over it that I shall never again think that a man must be playful always, and never earnest, because he is merry at times. I suppose he saw something in my face which checked him, for he suddenly stopped, and said with a sort of manly fervour that I could have loved him for if I had been free:--
"'Lucy, you are an honest-hearted girl, I know. I should not be here speaking to you as I am now if I did not believe you clean grit, right through to the very depths of your soul. Tell me, like one good fellow to
